questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of slowed growth and fatigue. Over the past year, she went from average height for her age group to the shortest in her class. She has also been having more problems concentrating in class and is less interested in playing. She has not had any change in appetite or diet. She is at the 10th percentile for height and the 90th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is a nontender mass palpated on the anterior neck during cervical examination. Serum laboratory studies show thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 6.7 μU/mL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration on fine needle aspiration
Positive serum thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibody
Solitary hot nodule on I-131 scan

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increased ESR in a patient with goiter may indicate subacute thyroiditis, which most often occurs in women 30–50 years and presents with a painful, diffuse, and firm goiter, and a clinical course of hyperthyroidism, followed by hypothyroidism, and finally a return to euthyroidism over the span of several months. In a subtype, called subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis, the goiter is painless. While this child presents with a nontender cervical mass and hypothyroidism, in her age group the condition is extremely rare. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, ESR is usually normal.

B) INCORRECT:

An elevated serum calcitonin is highly sensitive, but non-specific, for medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Children with MTC typically present with an asymptomatic solitary nodule. However, MTC is not typically associated with clinical hypo- or hyperthyroidism. Moreover, MTC in children is highly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 (MEN 2); this patient has no evidence to suggest MEN 2A (e.g., symptoms of pheochromocytoma, symptoms of hyperparathyroidism) or MEN 2B (e.g., marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas).

C) CORRECT:

Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration next to germinal centers (i.e., sites of antibody-secreting plasma cells), Hurthle cells, and fibrotic tissue are characteristic findings of Hashimoto thyroiditis. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, T-lymphocytes are cytotoxic to thyroid epithelial cells and stimulate B lymphocytes to produce autoantibodies (e.g., anti-peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin), which results in progressive destruction of thyroid tissue and consequent hypothyroidism. Lifelong oral administration of L-thyroxine (T4) is the treatment of choice.

Other causes of pediatric hypothyroidism include thyroid dysgenesis (most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in areas with adequate iodine intake), iodine deficiency, TSH receptor resistance, and other rare conditions affecting the formation and transport of thyroid hormone.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

The thyroid tissue in the lower half of the image is inflamed, as evidenced by the lymphocytic infiltrate (numerous purple dots) and dilated, congested blood vessels (examples indicated by arrows). Prominent lymphoid follicles with a germinal center (example indicated by orange overlay) surrounded by a hypercellular parafollicular region (example indicated by green overlay) are visible in the inflamed region. Normal thyroid follicles (example indicated by blue overlay) are visible in the top half of the image but are absent in the inflamed region.

Lymphocytic infiltration, lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, and destruction of thyroid follicles are characteristic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (TRAb) are most characteristic of Graves disease (> 90% of cases). While patients with Graves disease also present with goiter, they have hyperthyroidism, rather than hypothyroidism as seen in this patient. TRAb are also found in up to 15% of patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, but thyroid peroxidase antibodies (> 90%) and thyroglobulin antibodies (∼ 50%) are much more common. Although this patient may be positive for TRAbs, another finding is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased uptake on I-131 (i.e., radioactive iodine) scan in a discrete area (i.e., a solitary, hot nodule) is characteristic of a toxic adenoma, which typically affects adults 30–50 years of age and causes hyperthyroidism, rather than hypothyroidism as seen in this patient. Toxic adenomas are uncommon in children and radionuclide scanning is rarely indicated in children with primary hypothyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

Low urine iodine levels indicate iodine deficiency, which can lead to hypothyroidism and goiter. However, with the introduction of iodized salt in the 1920's, iodine deficiency has become exceedingly rare in the US, making another condition much more likely. In developing countries where a low iodine diet is common, this patient's symptoms would most likely be the result of iodine deficiency.
questions.hint: This pediatric patient has fatigue, decreased growth velocity with weight gain, goiter, and elevated TSH, which are all consistent with primary hypothyroidism. In areas with adequate iodine intake, Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in both children and adults.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of anxiety, difficulty falling asleep, heat intolerance, and a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. Examination shows warm, moist skin and a 2-cm, nontender, subcutaneous mass on the anterior neck. The patient's nephew, who is studying medicine, told her that her symptoms suggest a condition that is caused by gain-of-function mutations of TSH receptor genes. On further examination, which of the following findings would suggest a different etiology than the one described by the patient's nephew?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proximal muscle weakness can occur in the setting of thyrotoxic myopathy, a neuromuscular disorder that is associated with hyperthyroidism. Additional features include muscle wasting and myalgia. However, proximal muscle weakness is a nonspecific symptom and does not indicate a specific cause of hyperthyroidism.

B) CORRECT:

Myxedema (nonpitting edema) is specific for hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease, which is caused by TSH receptor antibodies rather than gain-of-function mutations of TSH receptor genes. Although the majority of symptoms of hyperthyroidism are caused by increased thyroid hormone levels (i.e., nonspecific), myxedema and exophthalmos are specific to Graves disease. These findings are due to autoantibody-mediated activation of TSH receptors in peripheral tissue. TSH receptor antibodies stimulate dermal fibroblasts and periorbital adipocytes, thereby increasing glycosaminoglycan synthesis. Deposition of these mucopolysaccharides is the underlying pathogenesis of myxedema and exophthalmos, which are specific to hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left knee and lower leg

There are numerous irregular nodules and plaques on the pretibial surface, and the skin has a red-brown discoloration. The hair follicles are prominent, resulting in an orange-peel (peau d'orange) appearance.

These are characteristic features of pretibial myxedema.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation is a common finding in patients with hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation. However, atrial fibrillation is a nonspecific symptom and does not indicate a specific cause of hyperthyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with hyperthyroidism commonly present with increased deep tendon reflexes. The underlying pathogenesis of hyperreflexia in the setting of hyperthyroidism is increased activity of Na+/K+-ATPase, which leads to hyperexcitability of neurons. However, hyperreflexia is a nonspecific symptom and does not indicate a specific cause of hyperthyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

The finding of lid lag can be caused by hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones increase sympathetic activity, which can lead to spasms of the smooth muscle in the levator palpebrae superioris. In contrast to Graves ophthalmopathy, lid lag is a nonspecific symptom and does not indicate a specific cause of hyperthyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with hyperthyroidism commonly present with a fine tremor caused by excess thyroid hormones, which cause sympathetic overactivity (increased activity of beta-adrenergic receptors). However, fine tremor is a nonspecific symptom and does not indicate a specific cause of hyperthyroidism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with classic symptoms of hyperthyroidism. The patient's nephew is describing the pathophysiology of toxic adenoma and toxic multinodular goiter. One of the answer options is specific for a different cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and a 5.4-kg (11.9-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. She appears anxious. Her pulse is 104/min and blood pressure is 148/101 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm skin, mild tremor, and an enlarged thyroid gland. A thyroid scintigraphy scan shows several focal areas with increased uptake. A biopsy of one of these areas of affected thyroid tissue is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Sheets of parafollicular cells surrounded by amyloid stroma
Inflammatory infiltrate with multinucleated giant cells and granuloma formation
Follicle destruction with lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal center formation
Patches of enlarged follicular cells distended with colloid
Crowded follicular cells with scalloped colloid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sheets of parafollicular cells surrounded by amyloid stroma would be consistent with medullary carcinoma, a type of poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland that typically arises sporadically but may be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Early symptoms tend to be mild, although some patients develop firm, painless thyroid nodules. In contrast to this patient, signs of hyperthyroidism would not be expected, and thyroid scintigraphy would not have increased uptake.

B) INCORRECT:

An inflammatory infiltrate with multinucleated giant cells and granuloma formation would be consistent with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (giant cell thyroiditis), a transient and self-resolving patchy inflammation of the thyroid gland that most commonly occurs after viral upper respiratory infection. The clinical course is typically triphasic, beginning first with hyperthyroidism, then hypothyroidism, and finally reaching a euthyroid state. In contrast to this patient, a diffuse decrease in radioiodine uptake would be expected on scintigraphy and this patient also lacks other classical clinical features such as tender goiter, elevated ESR, and jaw pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Follicle destruction with lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal center formation would be consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis. This is caused by autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid tissue, and manifests initially with hyperthyroidism, before progressing to hypothyroidism. The appearance of radioactive iodine uptake on scintigraphy is highly variable in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

D) CORRECT:

Focal patches of hyperfunctioning follicular cells are a histopathological feature of toxic multinodular goiter, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism after Graves disease. Toxic multinodular goiter is most commonly caused by chronic iodine deficiency, which decreases hormone production and thereby increases pituitary TSH secretion due to missing negative feedback. This leads to persistent stimulation of the thyroid gland, causing hyperplasia of thyroid nodules. In addition to the scintigraphy seen here, other characteristic findings include ↑ T3 and ↓ TSH. Scintigraphy is especially important when trying to differentiate between toxic multinodular goiter and Graves disease; in Graves disease, there is usually diffuse uptake on scintigraphy rather than focal areas of uptake.
Image Description:

Overview of radioactive iodine uptake patterns in hyperthyroidism

Toxic MNG: Toxic multinodular goiter

E) INCORRECT:

Crowded follicular cells with scalloped colloid would be consistent with Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Circulating TSH receptor autoantibodies trigger an overstimulation of the thyroid leading to excess thyroid hormone production. However, thyroid scintigraphy would show a diffuse uptake of radioactive iodine rather than the focal areas of increased uptake seen here. Furthermore, this patient is missing other classic signs of Graves disease such as ophthalmopathy and pretibial myxedema.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, weight loss, warm skin, tremor) and a goiter. Her radioactive iodine scan shows several hyperfunctioning areas with increased uptake.
